paragraphs.context: The service debuted on September 7, 2006 as Amazon Unbox in the United States. On September 4, 2008, the service was renamed Amazon Video on Demand. The Unbox name still refers to the local program, which as of August 2014 is no longer available for downloading purchased instant videos. On February 22, 2011, the service rebranded as Amazon Instant Video and added access to 5,000 movies and TV shows for  Amazon Prime  members. On September 4, 2012, Amazon signed a deal with pay-TV channel  Epix  to feature movies on their streaming service, in a move to rival their competitor  Netflix. Additionally, in November 2013, Amazon premiered the comedies  Alpha House  and  Betas, which are original series available exclusively online via the Prime Instant Video service. Amazon offered the first three episodes of both series at once for free, with each subsequent episode released weekly thereafter for  Prime members.
